item.title: Neuromancer by William Gibson - Review
item.description:
Neuromancer by William Gibson

A Defining Work of Cyberpunk

William Gibson‚Äôs Neuromancer isn‚Äôt just a science fiction novel‚Äîit‚Äôs the foundational text of cyberpunk. Published in 1984, it imagined a future of networked computers, artificial intelligence, and human augmentation that has become remarkably prescient. The prose is dense and evocative, painting a neon-soaked world where the line between human and machine blurs. Case, our protagonist, is a damaged console cowboy navigating the digital frontier of cyberspace while entangled in corporate intrigue. ## Why It Still Matters Nearly 40 years later, Gibson‚Äôs vision of cyberspace‚Äîa term he coined‚Äîcontinues to influence how we think about the internet, virtual reality, and human-computer interaction. The novel‚Äôs exploration of AI consciousness remains relevant as we grapple with modern machine learning systems. Highly recommended for anyone interested in the origins of cyberpunk or speculative fiction that tackles technology‚Äôs impact on humanity.

item.title: Welcome to Unix SSG
item.description:
Welcome to the Unix Static Site Generator

This is a demonstration of a minimal static site generator built with standard Unix tools. ## Features - ‚úÖ Markdown processing with Pandoc - ‚úÖ YAML frontmatter parsing with yq
- ‚úÖ HTML templating with envsubst - ‚úÖ RSS feed generation - ‚úÖ Tag-based organization - ‚úÖ Parallel processing with Make - ‚úÖ Minimal dependencies ## Philosophy The Unix philosophy of ‚Äúdo one thing well‚Äù applied to static site generation: > Write programs that do one thing and do it well. Write programs to work together. Each component has a single responsibility: - pandoc converts markdown to HTML - yq processes YAML metadata
- envsubst handles template substitution - make orchestrates the build process ## Code Example

# Process all markdown files in parallel
find src -name "*.md" -type f | \
    xargs -P $(nproc) -I {} bin/process-markdown.sh {}

This approach minimizes dependencies while maintaining full functionality.

item.title: The Four Agreements
item.description:
The Four Agreements Review

Description

In The Four Agreements, don Miguel Ruiz reveals the source of self-limiting beliefs that rob us of joy and create needless suffering. Based on ancient Toltec wisdom, The Four Agreements offer a powerful code of conduct that can rapidly transform our lives to a new experience of freedom, true happiness, and love. ## Review I purchased the paperback version but ended up listening to the audiobook version while doing chores over the weekend (~2.5 hours). This book gets straight to the point. That point being, throughout our lives we enter into agreements with society that enforce beliefs and influence our behavior, happiness, and inner peace. By speaking with truth and love, not suffering from main character syndrome (not everything is about you), seeking to understand rather than make assumptions, and not striving for perfection but constant improvement, you can slowly create new agreements that are more in line with your higher self.

item.title: Hello World
item.description: Welcome to my personal blog. This will be a blog post for documenting my learning process as well as sharing projects and ideas I come across. I often find myself doing things, researching how to do them and completing a task. A few weeks/months later I might have to do something similar and have to go through the process again. Using this blog will help me keep me reference that knowledge.

item.title: First note in the Unix SSG
item.description: Just testing out the Unix-based static site generator. This is a note-type post to demonstrate different content types. Pretty cool how pandoc + yq + make can replace a complex F# application! üöÄ

item.title: Unix Philosophy Explained
item.description: Great video explaining the Unix philosophy and how it applies to modern development. The key principles: 1. Do one thing well 2. Work together 3. Handle text streams
